[[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] | branch = [[United States Army]]

[[File:Union Army colonel rank insignia.png|35px]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]], [[United States Volunteers|USV]]
[[File:Union Army brigadier general rank insignia.svg|35px]] [[Brevet (military)|Bvt.]] [[Brigadier General (United States)|Brigadier General]] | unit = [[4th Infantry Regiment (United States)|4th United States Infantry]]
[[8th Infantry Regiment (United States)|8th U.S. Infantry]]

[[American Civil War]] }} '''Milton Cogswell''' (December 4, 1825 – November 20, 1882) was a [[United States Army]] officer. Milton Cogswell was born in [[Noblesville, Indiana]] on December 4, 1825. He graduated from the [[United States Military Academy]] at West Point in 1849, when he was appointed brevet Second Lieutenant in the [[4th Infantry Regiment (United States)|4th United States Infantry]]. In 1850 he was assigned to duty on the frontier, serving with the [[8th Infantry Regiment (United States)|8th Infantry]], but he was recalled and detailed as Assistant Professor of Mathematics at West Point until 1856.{{cite web | title=Col. Milton Cogswell (obituary) | work=New York Times | date=November 21, 1882 | accessdate=January 19, 2014}} When the Civil War broke about, Cogswell went into active service. In July, 1861, he was made Colonel of the [[42nd New York Volunteer Infantry Regiment|Forty-Second New York Volunteers]], and at the [[Battle of Ball's Bluff]] was captured by the Confederates and incarcerated in [[Libby Prison]], until being exchanged. At the close of the war he was assigned to garrison duty at Baltimore, and afterward served as Acting Judge-Advocate of the Department of North Carolina. In 1868 he was made Provisional Mayor of [[Charleston, South Carolina]] from March to July and was placed in charge of civil affairs at [[Summerville, South Carolina|Summerville]]. He was afterward performed various duties in the South and on the Western frontier until 1871, when he retired from active service on account of a disability contracted in the line of duty. He died on November 20, 1882, and is buried at Arlington Cemetery.{{cite web | url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=16367586 | title=Milton Cogswell (1825-1882) | publisher=Find a Grave | accessdate=January 19, 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{S-start}} {{Succession box | before = [[William Wallace Burns]] | title = [[Mayor of Charleston, South Carolina]] | years = 1868 | after = [[George Washington Clark]] }} {{S-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cogswell, Milton}} [[Category:Mayors of Charleston, South Carolina]] [[Category:1825 births]] [[Category:1882 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:Union Army colonels]] [[Category:United States Army officers]] {{SouthCarolina-mayor-stub}}
